Tho' the wiſdom of ſchools, damn our art and our tools,
We can laugh at the fools of the colledge. (Chorus.)

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Now my friends we're poſſeſt, of the glorious cheſt,
Joyn hands and rejoice beyond meaſure;
Let it be our firſt care, that great bleſſing to ſhare,
Whoſe contents are an infinite treaſure. (Chorus.)

div.stage: The dupes take up the cheſt, and bear it off, guarded by the humoriſts: going off they ſay,

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: It feels brave and ponderous

sp.speaker: Truſ
sp.p: It is ſo, my dare, but fait I don't care if I broke my back wid it—Arra dare trad off my hales.

sp.speaker: M' Sn.
sp.p: I beg your pordon mon.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Fait my dare, and you're wery welcome, for the devil burn me if I'm thinking about my hales, at all at all. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. A Room in Waſhball's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Bleſs me! how could you venture, after the ſevere reproof my uncle gave you, to approach this houſe, at this dead time of night?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Love! angelick love! which knows no fear, but your diſpleaſure, has brought me here on eagle's wings, to waft you hence, and ſeal that vow already ratified in heaven.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But conſider, my dear Meanwell! what may be the conſequence of ſuch a raſh ſtep, when perhaps a few days perſeverance may bring matters to a concluſion, with his conſent.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I cannot think of truſting to any thing ſo precarious, as he has already conſented, by being my bonds-man for the licence, and publickly declaring his aſſent, we ſhall be look'd upon by the honeſt and judicious, as ſufficiently juſtify'd in taking this ſtep.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am confounded! my love to you, ſpurs me to a flight, but my duty to my uncle, commands me to wait his reconciliation—I know not what to do, or what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
Haſte! haſte! my dear Lucy, we've no time
to loſe; each moment ſeems an hour till we're one; the clergyman waits with choſen friends, to tye the nuptial knot, and crown our bliſs.

lg.head: AIR XV. Kitty, the Nonpareile.
lg.l: Lucy ſings. My throbbing heart muſt now give way,
To love, to honor and obey,
Lo! Hymen's torch is lighted. Lo! Hymen's, &c.
My heart, my all, I do reſign,
Oh! Meanwell, Meanwell, I'll be thine,
In wedlocks bands united. In wedlocks, &c.
Meanwell ſings. Of Venus' charms, let poets write,
Diana chaſte, or Juno bright,
Of Kitty, Doll, or Suſey: Of Kitty, &c.
The charms of all are center'd here,
In Lucy, charming Lucy dear!
Haſte! haſte! my lovely Lucy. Haſte, &c.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p:
I can't bear the thoughts of dividing, not I— Diviſion, why, I never could learn it at ſchool— one hundred thouſand pounds, divided into nine parts— let me ſee— nine times nine is, a, a, eighty-nine; that's wrong; nine times eleven is an hundred and ſix and four over; that's too much; but I'm no ſcholar; well never mind, no matter; charity begins at home, and he muſt be muſt be the greateſt fool on earth that cheats himſelf: I think I'm old enough to have more wit—He that cheats another can wipe off the ſin by reſtoring four-fold; but he that cheats himſelf, the ſin will lie at his own door, and it will be out of his power to make himſelf reſtitution— I'll go and inform the collector; then I ſhall have one half to myſelf, the other will go to the king —They'll call me traytor, but I don't care, let them laugh that wins—It's an old ſaying,
and a true one—that is—let me ſee—aye, I have it, One bird in hand is better far, Than two that's in the puſh—no, no, Than two that in the buſhes are. Aye, that's it; I remember it's ſo on my neighbour Symonds's ſign; but here's fifty thouſand birds in the cage, and all pre • ty yellow-birds every one of them— Oh! they'll make delightful muſick, and make me ſing too—I'll e'en go to the collector; I muſt'n't loſe any time, no, no; (He looks up) I think this is the houſe; aye He knocks at the door, the collecter appears.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What is your buſineſs ſir?

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Why, why, ſir, I have an information to make you, concerning a cheſt of treaſure, that was dug out of the ground laſt night—Mr. Hum, ſir, and ſeveral others are concern'd; and it grieves my conſcience to cheat the king of his lawful right; ſo, pray ſir, ſeize it inſtantly, for me and his majeſty. I expect all concern'd will be at my houſe immediately to open and ſhare it—Put the broad R on it and then we ſhall be ſafe —you muſt act for me and the king, and we'll reward you handſomely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Poh, poh, 'tis not poſſible; it's only ſome ſcheme to make you ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Indeed ſir, it's a real truth; for this piece of money (Shewing the piece) drop'd out of the cheſt, when we took it out of the ground—Look here ſir, ſee it— Pray be expeditious, do ſir be expeditious.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well ſir, if you inſiſt upon it, I muſt ſeize it

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: My loyalty to the king, obliges me to inſiſt upon it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'll wait on you.

div.head: SCENE V. A Room in Waſhball's Houſe.
div.stage: Scene opens and diſcovers M' Snip, Truſhoop and Raccoon, ſitting on the Cheſt, and old Gabriel, Waſhball's Servant, ſtanding by.
Enter Hum, Parchment, Quadrant and Rattletrap.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Gabriel, where's your maſter?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: He's juſt ſtep • d out ſir.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Will he be in ſoon?

sp.speaker: Gab
sp.p: Aye. I believe he will.

sp.speaker: Quad
sp.p: Oh! here he comes! but who the devil's that with him?

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: The collector! Egad, this is what I did not expect—It will not do to dupe him; we muſt let him into the ſecret. Aſide to Hum.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Leave that to me, [Enter Collector and Waſhball. Hum takes the Collector aſide and ſays] Sir I'm ſorry we have been the means of giving you this trouble; it's a ſcheme of diverſion only; pleaſe not to notice it.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: Juſt as I thought—Mr. Hum your ſervant; gentlemen yours.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Sir, ſir, I beg you'd ſtay— Pray do your duty.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Mr. Waſhball, It's an affair too intricate for me. I muſt firſt adviſe with the kings attorney. Exit.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh you curſed ould traytor! ar'nt you aſham'd of yourſalf to be chateing us after this way?

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: I never heard o ſuch a villain!

sp.speaker: Gab
sp.p: Here • s queer doings here. Aſide.

sp.speaker: M' Sn.
sp.p: Ye eenfamous auld ſcoondril; ye turn'd eenformer, to get the ane half to yourſel—but ye're oot mon. I'ſe a mind to leeghten your heed by ane of your luggs.

sp.speaker: Gab
sp.p: Worſe and worſe. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Rac
sp.p: What did you tink we were all fools, to be cheated by you.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.p: Nothing can equal this! open the cheſt gentlemen, who knows but the king's attorney will be upon our backs directly.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: A traytor, gentlemen, of all mankind is the moſt deſpicable wretch. You ſee, gentlemen that old curmudgeon thinks nothing of betraying his ſoul, for the ſake of his body not the leaſt regard to his ſolemn oath

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: How he abuſes my maſter. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: Mr. Truſhoop, where's your adz? open the cheſt.

sp.speaker: Truſ
sp.p: Augh fait! and here we are bote, at your ſharviſs my dare.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Strives to prevent them, Hum, Rattletrap, Parchment and Quaarant hold him, he ſtruggles to get from them and bawls) Where's the Collector? Mr. Collector —tou • h it at your peril, you villains! I'll ſwear robbery againſt you.

sp.speaker: Gab
sp.p: I believe they're going to rob my maſter Aſide.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Go on with your buſineſs gentlemen, open the cheſt. Truſhoop, Raccoon and M' Snip opening the cheſt.

sp.speaker: Waſh
sp.p: Touch it at your peril I ſay—it belongs to me and the king.

sp.speaker: Truſ
sp.p: Belong to de devil you teif— we'll ſoon ſee who'll feel the ſharing of it.

sp.speaker: Gab
sp.p: I never ſee the like before. Lifting up his hands.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Murder! murder! fire thieves! raviſhment! hell and fury!—Betty, Betty, bring down the bags you made—Run Gabriel, and call the Collector.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, I will, and I'll go for the conſtable; ſorrow on me but I believe they'll murder my maſter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Dere the cheſt opens.

sp.speaker: M' Sn
sp.p: It's aupen
sp.stage: They let Waſhball go, he runs towards the cheſt; the aupes all ſcramble to get their ſhares, and in the ſcuffle puſh down Waſhball and overſet the cheſt, out tumble the contents

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: (Riſing.) Give me my ſhare! give me my ſhare! give me my ſhare!
sp.stage: M' Snip, Truſhoop Raccoon and Waſhball look at one another confus'd.

sp.speaker: M' Sn.
sp.p: Hoot mon • what the de'els aw this? nathing but ſtaines—I k • n weel enough wha it is— de'el dom me ſirs, but I'll ha' jontlemen's ſaytisfakeſhon.

sp.speaker: Truſ
sp.p: Fait, and we're all humbugg'd.

sp.speaker: Rac
sp.p: De devil dis is a ſcheme of broder Hum's— I'll ſecond your reſolution Mr. M' Snip—do you gib de cha • lenge.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: By my ſhowl! and I've been made a fool of for the future; but I'll take care for the time paſt.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I didn't tink broder Hum wou'd ſerve me ſo; but egad! I'll inform de lodge of dis— Dere's Rattletrap too wid his ſtars and tings, plague on dem all; and has Mrs. Placket made de fool of me too wid her conjuring—It can't be, for I tink ſhe lobes me, or ſhe wou'dn't call me her Cooney, and her cock-a-dandy— Dad I'll get a bottle of her water, and carry it to doctor Witt's, den I'll know if ſhe's a conjurer or not.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh I taught I ſhou'd be cannonicled for a ſhaint; but it's all over—Arra curſe theſe generations of ſnakes— I mane wipers.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh! I'm abus'd— I ſhall die, O dear! I ſhall die (Lifting up his hands.) Poor Waſhball, diſappointed Waſhball (Hum, Quadrant, Parchment and Rattletrap alternately calling canoe; Waſhball chaſing them about the ſtage, and endeavouring to ſtrike them with his cane.) Get out of my houſe, you villains! (They halloo canoe.) you curſed villains! (Canoe again.) you dogs! (Canoe.) you hell hounds! (Canoe.) you devils▪ (Canoe) curſe you all! (Canoe) They laugh and run off the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Arra this is the devil's own works, and they're all the devil's own children; by my ſhowl! and they'll do grate pannance for this. Sings.

lg.head: AIR XVI. The Milking Pail. (To be ſung ſlow, and with an Iriſh accent)
I.
lg.l: Arra what a fool was I; by my ſhowl! I think I'll cry,
When I ſpake of all thiſh, it encraaſes my bliſh;
'Twill kill me afore I die.
Fait I'll now ſhow m • faaſh, t'eſcape all diſgraaſh,
For me they • ll make a true jaſt.
No more will my foes,
Drive me by my noſe,
In bogs o'er my toes,
Spoiling brogues and ſhoes,
And carry the ampty chaſt.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Augh! feel my back is quite ſoar, fait becaze it made me roar.
How it broke all my bones, by pulling bricks and ſtones,
To the mill from Waſhball's dore.
To hear the pain and ſmart, I fale juſt in my haart,
My fut is both ſick and lame.
With canew and bote,
My wife'll cut my trote,
The de'el take the tote;
Augh me! they'll make a great game.

sp.speaker: M' Sn.
sp.p: De'el dom 'em aw.

sp.speaker: Rac
sp.p: Dis, dis is my own faut for being too credulous: I put too much confidence in doſe I tought my friends, and dey deceib'd me. Had I been ſatisfy'd wid my ſtation, and follow'd a birtuous courſe of life, den I might have been happy to dis day, and had noting to trouble my peace of mind.—But now I hab ſeen my folly and former bickedneſs, I bill take de reſolution to lead a new life, and follow my bus'neſs wid honeſty and induſtry, and hab noting more to ſay to de banities, bexations and alewments of dis world; and from hencefoat my ſtudy ſhall be birtue, which paat I will purſue to the end of my day.

sp.speaker: M' Sn.
sp.p: Confuſion to the vullains; I muſt e'en gang and fut up my ſhap-boord agen.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p:
O dear, I'm robb • d of my money, my health and my eaſe—nothing's left for me now but to grieve and lament—How ſhall I procure my peace again▪— Let me ſee—attend my buſineſs—what then—if a cuſtomer ſhould laugh under the operation of my razor, egad, I ſhou'd think he aim'd at me, for being this ſilly old fool, and ten to one but I might cut his throat for madneſs—Dreſs a wig—ha— I ſhall think my blocks grin at me—I'll inſtantly go and burn them all— If I hear the noiſe of children in the ſtreet, I ſhall think they bawl canoe, canoe—Confound this word—I'd give five hundred pound it was was made high treaſon to utter it; then I wou'd hang every one of thoſe curſed rogues— O dear! what can I do?—If I rail againſt them publickly, I ſhall only have the cold comfort of, "'Tis a piece of diverſion, nothing elſe"—Helliſh diverſion—Suppoſe I
ſhou'd try to laugh it off—Alas! alas! I can't do it— I ſhan't be in a laughing humour theſe ſeven years I'm afraid.

div.stage: Enter Meanwell and Lucy. (They kneel down.)

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Sir we crave your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Go to the devil you dog

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Augh Lucy! ſure you're not marry'd.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: It is ſo Mr. Truſhoop— Pray endeavour to pacify my uncle— pray gentlemen interpoſe.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh the gipſey! I ſhall run ſtark ſtaring mad.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Come, come, Mr. Waſhball, how can you be ſo angry wid her 〈◊〉 ſhe's a pretty young cretur.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Pray ſir pardon us.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Pray uncle give us your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: Let me int • ate you ſir, to blaſs 'em.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I charge you both, tell me the truth, are you really married?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: 'Tis really ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Dear uncle it's true.

sp.speaker: Waſh
sp.p: O dear! O lack-a-day! Well, if the knot is ty'd, there's no untying it now.

sp.speaker: M' Sn
sp.p: Come, come mon gie 'em your bleſſing; troth ſhe • s a ſmirky bonny laſs.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Well, ſince it is ſo, God bleſs you both — riſe—but remember children, that bare walls makes giddy houſewives.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Sir, we thank you for your kind condeſcention, and I muſt now inform you that I have this day received a letter from Jamaica, giving an account of my uncle's death, incloſing a copy of his will; by which I underſtand he hath left me five thouſand pounds in caſh, with all his real and perſonal eſtate; a part of which caſh is remitted me, in the Brig Welcome, Capt. Truſty.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it—it revives my drooping ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
Notwithſtanding this fluſh of fortune, I bear the ſame reſpect to your neice as heretofore; and you
may depend ſir, I ſhall always make it my ſtudy to merit your eſteem.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: You have my bleſſing, and may you live comfortably together, and ſee many happy days, and be bleſt with a train of dutiful children, to comfort you in your old age—and, O! that I, who have one foot in the grave, and the other ſcarcely out, had been contented, then I ſhould have been happy in my old age, and not have involved myſelf in this labyrinth of trouble and confuſion—But let it be a warning to others, not to liſten to idle ſchemes, and give way to vain imaginations; which had nearly prov'd fatal to me—for he whoſe deſires are unbounded, and is weak enough to liſten to artful deſigning men, ſtands upon a dangerous precipice whoſe foundation muſt ſink and he innevitably periſh. Sings.

lg.head: AIR XVII. Ah! who is me, poor Walley cry'd.
lg.l: (To be ſung ſlow.) Ah! who is me, poor wretched I,
With broken heart and down caſt eyes;
To eaſe my mind where ſhall I fly?
A prey to knaves, poor Waſhball dies.
Let future generations take,
Example by my diſmal fall,
Nor gods of gold, or idols make,
So ſhun the fate of poor Waſhball.

sp.p: And now my friends, Mr. Truſhoop, Mr. M' Snip and Mr. Raccoon, I expect you will honor us with your company at dinner—We'll ſtrive to make ourſelves as merry as we can, and forget our folly.—Gabriel, call in the neighbours, bring your fiddle and play for us, and we'll have a dance,.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: (without.) I will ſir, ſorrow on me but I will, for we havn't had a dance ſince laſt chriſtmaſs.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: In the mean while, my children, give us a ſong.

lg.head: AIR XVIII. Jolly Bacchanalian.
lg.l: Meanwell ſings. Baniſh ſorrow welcome joy,
Let's ſtrike up the ſprightly dance;
Mirth abound without alloy;
Tune your lutes, your pipes advance;
Sound your notes in lofty ſtrains,
Joyn ye nymphs and jovial ſwains,
Baniſh care and be at reſt,

Of a bad bargain make the beſt. Baniſh care, &c.
Lucy ſings.
Room for joy, how bleſt am I,
In a huſband and a friend,
Virtuous love ſhall never die,
Tho' our lives will ſurely end.
Virgins all example take;
Virtue love, for virtue's ſake,
Conſtant be as turtle dove,
Let your theme be virtuous love. Conſtant be, &c.

div.stage: Enter Gabriel with his fiddle, and Neighbours: they ſtrike up a Country Dance, call • d EXCUSE ME.

lg.l: After the Dance Waſhball ſays, In ſearch of treaſure, we are led aſtray,
Believing fully, what deceivers ſay.
They tread unſure, who 'gainſt there ſenſes run,
Falſe ſteps purſue and ruſh to be undone,
Curs'd by themſelves, laugh'd at by ev'ry one. Exeunt.

div.head: EPILOGUE.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Down derry derry down▪ down down derry.

sp.speaker: Rattle.
sp.p: Maſter Hum▪ methinks your won'drous merry.

sp.speaker: Hum
sp.p: Gad, ſo I am.

sp.speaker: Rattle.
sp.l: That I can plainly ſee,

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Sing tantararara, rara, raree.

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.l: Of all the plays I ever ſaw or heard—

sp.speaker: Rattle.
sp.p: This beats them all, I ſwear now by my beard.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe you con • 'ring rogue, 'tis ſorry ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Your ſervant ma'am for you make noiſe enough
sp.stage: Hum, Quadrant and Rattletrap leave her, bowing.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.l: Zounds! what's this? the devil and all to pay;
Broadſide and broadſide, damn'd warm work to day,
I'll drop a ſtern and let them end the fray.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: 'Tis nonſenſe all, methinks I hear ſome ſay,
But hang 'em how they laugh'd and cla • t away:
There's one hoarſe voice he croak'd, 'tis very witty,
A female next ſqueak'd out, 'tis vaſtly pretty;
Lord! ſays a third, how it alarms the city.
Plague on them all, Oh! how I ſhall be teaz'd.

div.stage: Enter Meanwell and Lucy, lock'd arm in arm and croſs the Stage.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Encircled in thy arms▪ Oh! how I'm pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.l: Confound the play, it's made a wond'rous racket

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Oh ſplit 'em all, thro' breeches, coat and jacket

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Come, don't cry pet, don't cry my pretty Placket.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Oh monſtrous! laugh, and not one word of ſence.

sp.speaker: M' Sn
sp.p: But you ſee mon, it pleas'd the audience.

sp.speaker: Plac
sp.l: Aye to be ſure—but 'twas at our expence Crys.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: What fools theyv'e made of us—Oh dear! Oh dear!

sp.speaker: Truſ.
sp.p: That's true for you! but by my ſhowl 'twas queer.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.l: Oh ſhame! Oh ſhame! my rage is to exceſs

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: [without.] The boxes laugh'd aloud— you heard I gueſs.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: 'Twill drive me crazy— It's a mortal blow.

sp.speaker: Rattle.
sp.p: [without▪] Ne'er fear old cock— A digging we'll all go. Sings.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: Ridiculous ſcenes they were tranſacting.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: [without.] Aye, but how I laugh'd while it was acting.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: A play indeed!—a play ſhould have ſome wit.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: (without.) Pray who made you a judge? what ſaid the pit?

sp.speaker: Rattle.
sp.p: They laugh'd aloud and took a deal of notice.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: One girl I thought▪ Ha▪ ha, ſhe'd ſplit her bodice.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.l: The boxes clap'd — the ladies cry'd bleſs me

sp.speaker: Quad.
sp.p: So pleas'd they were, they laugh'd out, He, he, he.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.p: That dog Hum's a very wicked body.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Tol de rol, lol de rol, tol de rol loddy. Sings.

sp.speaker: Waſh.
sp.l: Come, come away, for this will never do.
Good Night t'ye all.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Canoe.

sp.speaker: Parch.
sp.p: Canoe.

sp.speaker: Rattle.
sp.p: Canoe.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: In the Title page, for wordling, read worldling.
In the Prologue, for inſtruſt, read inſtruct.
